frames.processing

Class Scene

  • java.lang.Object
    • frames.core.Graph
      • frames.processing.Scene
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    PConstants

    public class Scene
extends Graph
implements PConstants
    A 2D or 3D interactive, on-screen or off-screen, Processing Graph.

    Usage

    Typical usage comprises three steps: scene instantiation, setting an eye and setting some shapes.

    Scene instantiation

    Instantiate your on-screen scene at the PApplet.setup(): 
     
 Scene scene;
 void setup() {
   scene = new Scene(this);
 }
    The scene frontBuffer() corresponds to the PApplet main canvas.

    Off-screen scenes should be instantiated upon a PGraphics object: 

     
 Scene scene;
 PGraphics canvas;
 void setup() {
   canvas = createGraphics(500, 500, P3D);
   scene = new Scene(this, canvas);
 }
    In this case, the scene frontBuffer() corresponds to the canvas.

    The eye

    The scene eye can be an instance of Frame or a Node. To set the eye from a frame instance use code such as the following: 
     
 ...
 Frame eye;
 void setup() {
   ...
   eye = new Frame();
   scene.setEye(eye);
 }
    The eye can be controlled programmatically using the powerful Frame API.

    To set the eye from a node instance use code such as the following: 

     
 ...
 Node eye;
 void setup() {
   ...
   eye = new Node(scene) {
     public void interact(Event event) {
       if (event.shortcut().matches(new Shortcut(PApplet.LEFT)))
         translate(event);
     }
   };
   scene.setEye(eye);
   scene.setDefaultGrabber(eye);
 }
    The eye can be controlled both programmatically (since a Node is a Frame specialization) and interactively (using the mouse, see mouse() and Mouse). Note the use of the anonymous inner Node class used to define how the node will behave, refer to the Node API for details. Note also the Graph.setDefaultGrabber(Grabber) call which will direct input to the eye when no other node is being picked.

    Shapes

    A Shape is a Node specialization that can be set from a retained-mode rendering Processing PShape or from an immediate-mode rendering Processing procedure. Shapes can be picked precisely using their projection onto the screen, see Shape.setPrecision(Node.Precision). Use traverse() to render all scene-graph shapes or Shape.draw() to render a specific one instead.

    Retained-mode shapes

    To set a retained-mode shape use Shape shape = new Shape(Scene scene, PShape shape) or Shape shape = new Shape(Scene scene) and then call Shape.set(PGraphics).

    Immediate-mode shapes

    To set an immediate-mode shape use code such as the following: 
     
 ...
 Shape shape;
 void setup() {
   ...
   shape = new Shape(scene) {
     public void set(PGraphics canvas) {
       //immediate-mode rendering procedure
     }
   };
 }

    Note that shapes like nodes can be control interactively. Override Node.interact(Event), like it has been done above.

    Key-frame interpolators

    A frame (and hence a node or a shape) can be animated through a key-frame Catmull-Rom interpolator path. Use code such as the following: 
     
 Scene scene;
 PShape pshape;
 Shape shape;
 Interpolator interpolator;
 void setup() {
   ...
   shape = new Shape(scene, pshape);
   interpolator = new Interpolator(shape);
   for (int i = 0; i < random(4, 10); i++)
     interpolator.addKeyFrame(Node.random(scene));
   interpolator.start();
 }
    which will create a random (see Node.random(Graph)) interpolator path containing [4..10] key-frames (see Interpolator.addKeyFrame(Frame)). The interpolation is also started (see Interpolator.start()). The interpolator path may be drawn with code like this: 
     
 ...
 void draw() {
   scene.traverse();
   scene.drawPath(interpolator, 5);
 }
    while traverse() will draw the animated shape(s), drawPath(Interpolator, int) will draw the interpolated path too.

    Non-standard interactivity

    To control your scene nodes by means different than the mouse() (see Mouse), implement an Agent and call Graph.registerAgent(Agent).

    Drawing functionality

    There are several static drawing functions that complements those already provided by Processing, such as: drawCylinder(PGraphics, int, float, float), drawHollowCylinder(PGraphics, int, float, float, Vector, Vector), drawCone(PGraphics, int, float, float, float, float), drawCone(PGraphics, int, float, float, float, float, float) and drawTorusSolenoid(PGraphics, int, int, float, float).

    Drawing functions that take a PGraphics parameter (including the above static ones), such as beginScreenCoordinates(PGraphics), endScreenCoordinates(PGraphics), drawAxes(PGraphics, float), drawCross(PGraphics, float, float, float) and drawGrid(PGraphics) among others, can be used to set a Shape (see Shape.set(PGraphics)).

    Another scene's eye (different than this one) can be drawn with drawEye(Graph). Typical usage include interactive minimaps and visibility culling visualization and debugging.

      boolean hasAutoFocus()
      When having multiple off-screen scenes displayed at once, it should be decided which one will grab input from the mouse(), so that code like this: scene1.beginDraw(); drawScene1(); graph.endDraw(); graph.display(); scene2.beginDraw(); drawScene2(); scene2.endDraw(); scene2.display(); will behave according to a given focus policy.

             PGraphics pGraphics)
        Same as this(pApplet, pGraphics, 0, 0).

      • Scene

        public Scene(PApplet pApplet,
             PGraphics pGraphics,
             int x,
             int y)
        Main constructor defining a left-handed Processing compatible scene. Calls Graph.setMatrixHandler(MatrixHandler) using a customized MatrixHandler depending on the frontBuffer() type (see Java2DMatrixHandler and GLMatrixHandler). The constructor instantiates also the mouse().

        An off-screen Processing scene is defined if pGraphics != pApplet.g. In this case the x and y parameters define the position of the upper-left corner where the off-screen scene is expected to be displayed, see display(). If pGraphics == pApplet.g) (which defines an on-screen scene, see also isOffscreen()), the values of x and y are meaningless (both are set to 0 to be taken as dummy values). Render into an off-screen graph requires the drawing code to be enclose by beginDraw() and endDraw(). To display an off-screen scene call display().

        See Also:
        Graph.Graph(int, int), Scene(PApplet), Scene(PApplet, PGraphics)

      • setCenterFromPixel

        public boolean setCenterFromPixel(Point pixel)
        The Graph.center() is set to the point located under pixel on screen.

        2D windows always returns true.

        3D Cameras returns true if a point was found under pixel and false if none was found (in this case no Graph.center() is set).

      • pixelDepth

        public float pixelDepth(Point pixel)
        Returns the depth (z-value) of the object under the pixel. Used by pointUnderPixel(Point).

        The z-value ranges in [0..1] (near and far plane respectively). In 3D note that this value is not a linear interpolation between Graph.zNear() and Graph.zFar(): z = zFar() / (zFar() - zNear()) * (1.0f - zNear() / z') where z' is the distance from the point you project to the eye, along the Graph.viewDirection().

        See Also:
        pointUnderPixel(Point)

      • pointUnderPixel

        public Vector pointUnderPixel(Point pixel)
        Returns the world coordinates of the 3D point located at pixel (x,y) on screen. May be null if no object is under pixel.

      • pre

        public void pre()
        Paint method which is called just before your PApplet.draw() method. Simply calls Graph.preDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it. Only meaningful if the graph is on-screen (it the graph isOffscreen() it even doesn't get registered at the PApplet.

        If frontBuffer() is resized then (re)sets the graph Graph.width() and Graph.height(), and calls Graph.setWidth(int) and Graph.setHeight(int).

        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.preDraw(), Graph.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), isOffscreen()

      • draw

        public void draw()
        Paint method which is called just after your PApplet.draw() method. Simply render the back buffer (useful for picking) and call Graph.postDraw(). This method is registered at the PApplet and hence you don't need to call it. Only meaningful if the graph is on-screen (it the graph isOffscreen() it even doesn't get registered at the PApplet.

        If isOffscreen() does nothing.

        See Also:
        pre(), Graph.preDraw(), Graph.postDraw(), beginDraw(), endDraw(), isOffscreen()

      • isOffscreen

        public boolean isOffscreen()
        Returns true if this scene is off-screen and false otherwise.

      • beginDraw

        public void beginDraw()
        Only if the scene isOffscreen(). Calls frontBuffer().beginDraw() (hence there's no need to explicitly call it) and then Graph.preDraw() .

        If frontBuffer() is resized then (re)sets the graph Graph.width() and Graph.height(), and calls Graph.setWidth(int) and Graph.setHeight(int).

        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.preDraw(), Graph.postDraw(), pre(), endDraw(), isOffscreen(), frontBuffer()

      • endDraw

        public void endDraw()
        Only if the dcene isOffscreen(). Calls:
        1. frontBuffer().endDraw() and hence there's no need to explicitly call it
        2. _renderBackBuffer(): Render the back buffer (useful for picking)
        3. Graph.postDraw()
        4. _handleFocus() if hasAutoFocus() is true

        Graph.postDraw().

        See Also:
        draw(), Graph.preDraw(), Graph.postDraw(), beginDraw(), pre(), isOffscreen(), frontBuffer()

      • display

        public void display()
        Same as display(frontBuffer()). Only meaningful if the graph isOffscreen().
        See Also:
        display(PGraphics), frontBuffer()

      • display

        public void display(PGraphics pgraphics)
        Same as pApplet().image(pgraphics, originCorner().x(), originCorner().y()). Only meaningful if the graph isOffscreen().

      • hasAutoFocus

        public boolean hasAutoFocus()
        When having multiple off-screen scenes displayed at once, it should be decided which one will grab input from the mouse(), so that code like this: 
         
 scene1.beginDraw();
 drawScene1();
 graph.endDraw();
 graph.display();
 scene2.beginDraw();
 drawScene2();
 scene2.endDraw();
 scene2.display();

        will behave according to a given focus policy. This property is enabled by default and it implements a "focus follows mouse" policy, so that the scene under the cursor will grab input. If multiple scenes overlaps the scene on top will grab the input as expected.

        To implement a different policy either:

        1. Override the _hasFocus() scene method; or,
        2. Call disableAutoFocus() and implement your own focus policy at the sketch space.
        Note that for this policy to work, you should call display() instead of the papplet image() function on the frontBuffer().
        See Also:
        beginDraw(), endDraw(), display(), enableAutoFocus(), disableAutoFocus(), toggleAutoFocus()

      • toggleAutoFocus

        public void toggleAutoFocus()
        Toggles the scene auto-focus property.
        See Also:

      • traverse

        public void traverse(PGraphics pGraphics)
        Draw all Graph.nodes() into the given pGraphics. No pGraphics.beginDraw()/endDraw() calls take place. This method allows shader chaining.

        Note that drawNodes(backBuffer()) (which enables 'picking' of the nodes using a 'ray-picking' technique is called by Graph.postDraw(). Attention: this method should be called after _bind(PGraphics) (i.e., manual eye update) and before any other transformation of the modelview takes place.

        Parameters:
        pGraphics -
        See Also:
        Graph.nodes(), traverse()

      • matrixHandler

        Note that the current graph matrix helper may be retrieved by Graph.matrixHandler().

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(Interpolator interpolator,
                     int mask,
                     int frameCount)
        Convenience function that simply calls drawPath(interpolator, mask, frameCount, radius()).
        See Also:
        drawPath(Interpolator, int, int, float)

      • drawPath

        public void drawPath(Interpolator interpolator,
                     int mask,
                     int frameCount,
                     float scale)
        Draws the path used to interpolate the Interpolator.frame()

        mask controls what is drawn: If ( (mask & 1) != 0 ), the position path is drawn. If ( (mask & 2) != 0 ), an eye representation is regularly drawn and if ( (mask & 4) != 0 ), oriented axes are regularly drawn. Examples:

        drawPath(1); // Simply draws the interpolation path
        drawPath(3); // Draws path and eyes
        drawPath(5); // Draws path and axes

        In the case where the eye or axes are drawn, frameCount controls the number of objects (axes or eyes) drawn between two successive key-frames. When frameCount = 1, only the key-frames are drawn, when frameCount = 2 it also draws the intermediate orientation, etc. The maximum value is 30, so that an object is drawn for each key-frame. Default value is 6.

        scale controls the scaling of the eye and axes drawing. A value of Graph.radius() should give good results.

        public static void drawHollowCylinder(PGraphics pGraphics,
                                      float radius,
                                      float height,
                                      Vector normal1,
                                      Vector normal2)

        drawHollowCylinder(PGraphics, int, float, float, Vector, Vector)

      • drawHollowCylinder

        public static void drawHollowCylinder(PGraphics pGraphics,
                                      int detail,
                                      float radius,
                                      float height,
                                      Vector normal1,
                                      Vector normal2)
        Draws a hollow cylinder onto pGraphics whose bases are formed by two cutting planes (normal1 and normal2), along the positive z axis.
        Parameters:
        detail -
        radius - radius of the hollow cylinder
        height - height of the hollow cylinder
        normal1 - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=0
        normal2 - normal of the plane that intersects the cylinder at z=height
        See Also:
        drawCylinder(float, float)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(Graph graph)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(Graph graph,
                    boolean texture)
        Applies the graph.eye() transformation and then calls drawEye(PGraphics, Graph, boolean) on the scene frontBuffer(). If texture draws the projected scene on the near plane.
        See Also:
        Graph.applyTransformation(Frame), drawEye(PGraphics, Graph, boolean)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(PGraphics pGraphics,
                    Graph graph)
        Same as drawEye(pGraphics, graph, false).
        See Also:
        drawEye(PGraphics, Graph, boolean)

      • drawEye

        public void drawEye(PGraphics pGraphics,
                    Graph graph,
                    boolean texture)
        Draws a representations of the graph.eye() onto pGraphics. If texture draws the projected scene on the near plane.

        Warning: texture only works with opengl renderers.

        Note that if graph == this this method has not effect at all.

      • drawEyeNearPlane

        public void drawEyeNearPlane(Graph graph)

      • drawEyeNearPlane

        public void drawEyeNearPlane(Graph graph,
                             boolean texture)
        Applies the graph.eye() transformation and then calls drawEyeNearPlane(PGraphics, Graph, boolean) on the scene frontBuffer(). If texture draws the projected scene on the near plane.
        See Also:
        drawEyeNearPlane(PGraphics, Graph, boolean), Graph.applyTransformation(Frame), drawEye(PGraphics, Graph, boolean)

      • drawEyeNearPlane

                             Graph graph,
                             boolean texture)

        Warning: texture only works with opengl renderers.

        Note that if graph == this this method has not effect at all.

      • drawProjectors

        public void drawProjectors(PGraphics pGraphics,
                           Graph graph,
                           java.util.List<Vector> points)
        Draws the projection of each point in points in the near plane onto pGraphics.

        This method should be used in conjunction with drawEye(PGraphics, Graph, boolean).

        Note that if graph == this this method has not effect at all.

        See Also:
        drawProjector(PGraphics, Graph, Vector)

      • drawCross

        public void drawCross(Frame frame)
        drawCross(float, float, float) centered at the projected frame origin. If frame is a Node instance the length of the cross is the node Node.precisionThreshold(), otherwise it's Graph.radius() / 5. If frame a Node instance and it is Graph.isInputGrabber(Grabber) it also applies a stroke highlight.
        See Also:
        drawShooterTarget(Frame, float)

      • drawCross

        public void drawCross(Frame frame,
                      float length)
        drawCross(float, float, float) centered at the projected frame origin, having length pixels.
        See Also:
        drawCross(float, float, float)

      • drawCross

                      float y)

      • drawShooterTarget

        public void drawShooterTarget(Frame frame)
        drawShooterTarget(float, float, float) centered at the projected frame origin. If frame is a Node instance the length of the target is the node Node.precisionThreshold(), otherwise it's Graph.radius() / 5. If frame a Node instance and it is Graph.isInputGrabber(Grabber) it also applies a stroke highlight.
        See Also:
        drawShooterTarget(Frame, float)

        public static void drawTorusSolenoid(PGraphics pGraphics,
                                     int faces,
                                     int detail,
                                     float insideRadius,
                                     float outsideRadius)
        Draws a torus solenoid onto pGraphics.

        Code contributed by Jacques Maire (http://www.alcys.com/) See also: http://www.mathcurve.com/courbes3d/solenoidtoric/solenoidtoric.shtml http://crazybiocomputing.blogspot.fr/2011/12/3d-curves-toric-solenoids.html

        Parameters:
        faces -
        detail -
        insideRadius -
        outsideRadius -

                     float height,
                     float a,

        b -

      • drawCone

        public void drawCone(PGraphics pGraphics,
                     java.util.List<Vector> vertices,
                     float scale)
        Draws a cone onto pGraphics centered at (0,0,0) where vertices represents the base of the Polygon and with scale as maximum height.

        It is desirable that each point in vertices lie inside the unit Sphere

        Parameters:
        pGraphics -
        vertices -
        scale -
